questions.text: Which of the following is not an orphan drug?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen is not an orphan drug. It is an essential drug.

Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases.

Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for the pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

Few examples of orphan drugs:

  • Miltefosine
  • Sodium nitrite
  • Succimer
  • Rifabutin
  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

  • The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palanosetron.
     
  • The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palanosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A patient experienced two acute asthma exacerbations within one month despite ongoing therapy. Which of the following systemic steroids is suitable for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Prednisolone is a systemic steroid used for maintenance therapy after an acute exacerbation of asthma.

Intravenous corticosteroids such as hydrocortisone are indicated if the lung function is predicted to be <30% or if there's poor response to nebulized β2 agonists. After the exacerbation, oral predisolone can be substituted with maximal beneficial effect at 30-40mg daily.

Inhaled corticosteroids commonly used in asthma are:

  • Beclomethasone dipropionate
  • Budesonide
  • Ciclesonide
  • Fluticasone
  • Mometasone

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of exenatide, that is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Exenatide is a GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

GLP-1 analogs are peptides and are generally given other than oral routes due to degradation by intestinal peptidases. But semaglutide was synthesized by adding sodium caprylate which increases its permeability and leads to its absorption before it gets degraded. Hence, it enabled oral usage of a GLP-1 analog.

Mechanism of Action: GLP-1 receptor agonists stimulate glucose-dependent insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells, suppress glucagon secretion from pancreatic α-cells, and delay gastric emptying.

GLP-1 analogs: Exenatide ,Liraglutide ,Albiglutide ,Dulaglutide, Lixisenatide ,Semaglutide

Other options:

Option A: Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Option C: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

Option D: Pramlintide is an islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) or amylin analog. Amylin analogs reduce glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying, and centrally decrease appetite.

Treatment with statins would depend on the overall cardiovascular risk (ASCVD) rather than specific LDL/HDL cholesterol level.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs come under Schedule H of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1945?

choices.text: Biologicals and special products like insulin, toxin and antitoxins
Drugs  purchased with the prescription of a qualified doctor
Drugs with a warning label  “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision”

questions.solution:
Schedule H includes drugs purchased over the counter with the prescription of a qualified doctor.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, classify drugs under different schedules based on their potential for abuse, their therapeutic value, and other factors. The rules provide guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Other options:

Option A- Biological and special products like insulin, toxin, and antitoxins are included under Schedule C.

Option B- Bacterial vaccines are included under Schedule F I.

Option D- Drugs that should be labelled with the words “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision” are included under Schedule G.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about methotrexate is false?

choices.text: Non-proliferative cells are resistant to it
It targets the S-phase of the cell cycle

questions.solution:
Folinic acid, also known as leucovorin, the active form of folic acid, is administered with methotrexate to reduce the toxicity associated with higher doses. It does not enhance the action of methotrexate.

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. It is a cell cycle (S-phase) specific antineoplastic agent and non-proliferative cells are relatively resistant to it. 

Bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal mucosa inflammation (mucositis) are the common side effects seen due to inhibition of DNA synthesis. 

Methotrexate toxicity:

  • Prevention - administration of leucovorin/folinic acid.
  • Treatment - maintaining adequate hydration and forced alkaline diuresis in patients with normal renal function.
  • Glucarpidase is an intravenous drug administered in patients who have impaired renal function.

questions.text: High-ceiling diuretics are used in the treatment of all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
High-ceiling diuretics or loop diuretics are not used in pulmonary hypertension.

Their diuretic property helps in removing the excess fluid in hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases and their vasodilatory and diuretic action is helpful for the quick relief of symptoms in LVF and acute pulmonary edema. They are also used for the treatment of chronic CHF.

Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition where there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance. Since nitric oxide is an important regulator of pulmonary vascular resistance, PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, or tadalafil are primarily used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Generalized edema occurs due to fluid retention in systemic tissues, commonly seen in conditions like heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, or chronic kidney disease. High-ceiling diuretics are effective here as they can rapidly reduce extracellular fluid volume by promoting diuresis.

Option B: Although loop diuretics are not the first-line treatment for cerebral edema, they may be used in conjunction with other therapies like mannitol to reduce intracranial pressure by decreasing overall fluid volume

Option C: Loop diuretics help reduce pulmonary congestion by decreasing preload and promoting diuresis.

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA in the nerve terminal. Identify the drug that acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The drug that acts at the site 'A' is baclofen.

Baclofen is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically. Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the α/γ interface of the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the frequency of the opening of the chloride channel. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone.

Option B: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used as an adjunct therapy for partial seizures with or without secondary generalization.

Option D: Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to α2δ protein. It is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of doxycycline?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Protein synthesis Inhibitors:

Antibacterial drugs which bind to the 30s subunit of the 70s ribosome are given below:

  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides

Antibacterial drugs which bind to the 50s subunit of 70s ribosome are given below:

  • Macrolides
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramins
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid

Other options:

Options A: Cefotetan and oxacillin are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.

Option D: Tavaborole inhibits fungal leucyl-tRNA synthetase, thereby inhibiting fungal protein synthesis and finally resulting in fungal cell death.

questions.text:
A patient scheduled for a CABG procedure receives preoperative heparin for anticoagulation. During the surgery, the patient starts bleeding massively and there is a drop in BP. Which of the following would you use to manage this patient?

CABG: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft
questions.solution:
Protamine sulfate is the drug used to treat life-threatening, heparin-induced bleeding.

It is a mixture of basic polypeptides isolated from salmon sperm. It binds to acidic heparin with high affinity and neutralizes anticoagulant activity. The resultant protamine-heparin complexes are cleared. Protamine binds only to long heparin molecules (UFH). Therefore, protamine only partially reverses the activity of LMWH and has no effect on fondaparinux. 

It is most commonly used to neutralize heparin-induced anticoagulation after separation from cardiopulmonary bypass. It is also utilized in the setting of dialysis, invasive vascular procedures, and acute ischemic strokes.

Note: Protamine sulfate has anticoagulant activity at higher doses and hence, only small amounts of protamine (1mg/100 units of heparin) are used for heparin-induced bleeding.

questions.text: A patient on long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin, would need an increase in dosage when coadministered with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A patient on long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin would need an increased in dosage when coadministered with rifampicin. This is because rifampicin is a potent microsomal enzyme inducer and can decrease the effect of warfarin.

Warfarin is cleared hepatically primarily via the CYP2C9 enzyme.

Rifampicin induces CYP3A and CYP2D6 enzymes. 

Enzyme inducers:

    • Phenobarbitone (CYP2B1)
    • Rifampicin (CYP2D6)
    • Phenytoin
    • Glucocorticoids
  • CYP2E1
    • Isoniazid
    • Chronic alcoholism

Note: Isoniazid is an inducer for CYP2E1 but an inhibitor for CYP3A4

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin?
questions.solution:
Cloxacillin is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Penicillinase is a beta-lactamase enzyme that inactivates penicillin by destroying the beta-lactam ring. This enzyme is produced by most staphylococci, some gonococci strains, Bacillus subtilis, E.coli, Hemophilus influenza etc..,

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are not inactivated by penicillinase. But, they are less efficient than penicillin G against penicillin-sensitive pathogens. They are used to treat staphylococcal infections that are sensitive to methicillin. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Other options:

Option A: Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally. But it has limited use against penicillinase-producing organisms.

Option C: Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting. They are given as deep I.M. injections. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks. It is sensitive to penicillinase. 

Option D: Ampicillin is an extended-spectrum penicillin but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female, a known case of sickle disease came with complaints of unprovoked pain in the extremities and torso. A thromboembolic episode was suspected. What is the first drug to be started for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a sickle cell crisis. This patient with unprovoked pain in the extremities and torso most likely has a thromboembolic episode. The first drug to be started for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events is heparin.

The mainstay of prophylaxis of thromboembolic events lies in anticoagulant medication. The initial parenteral therapy with heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux shifted to a novel oral anticoagulant like dabigatran with warfarin acting as a bridge drug, followed by a long oral monotherapy with rivaroxaban or apixaban for a few weeks.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with benign prostatic hypertrophy. The physician starts him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP.

Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin 
  • Doxazosin 
  • Alfuzosin 

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: An elderly patient with ventricular tachycardia has been started on amiodarone. Which of the following is the most important adverse event associated with this drug's use?
questions.solution:
The most important adverse event associated with the use of amiodarone is pulmonary fibrosis. 

Amiodarone is a class three anti-arrhythmic that is primarily used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in patients who take prolonged courses of amiodarone and in high doses.

Pulmonary fibrosis can be potentially life-threatening and requires immediate discontinuation of the amiodarone and initiation of high-dose corticosteroids.

Other adverse events associated with amiodarone use are nausea, photosensitivity, corneal microdeposits and thyroid dysfunction.

Other options:

Option B: Central nervous system toxicity. There are no significant central nervous system-related adverse events. In a minority of patients, peripheral neuropathy presenting as shoulder and pelvic muscle weakness is seen.

Option C: Renal dysfunction is not seen with Amiodarone since it is hepatically cleared.

Option D: Ototoxicity is associated with prolonged aminoglycoside use and is not a feature of amiodarone toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the drugs marked as A, B, and C.

choices.text: A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Vorapaxar
A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Prasugrel
A - Aspirin, B - Prasugrel, C - Eptifibatide

questions.solution:
The drugs marked A, B and C are aspirin, eptifibatide, and vorapaxar, respectively.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence, inhibition of its formation is responsible for antiplatelet action.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor and lasts for the entire lifetime of a platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients.

questions.text: Gynecomastia is an adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Spironolactone has an additional affinity towards progesterone and androgen receptors resulting in gynecomastia, loss of libido, menstrual irregularities, and other adverse effects.

Eplerenone has a lower affinity to progesterone and androgen receptors due to its 9,11 epoxide group. The incidence of gynecomastia and other effects are minimal with eplerenone.

Other options: Amiloride and furosemide are not associated with gynecomastia

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the drug allopurinol?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is recommended as the first-line urate-lowering agent in all patients with chronic gout. It is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.

It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. The metabolite of allopurinol called oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.  

Febuxostat is a uric acid synthesis inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management.

Both Febuxostat and Allopurinol are Xanthine Oxidase inhibitors, of which Allopurinol is a hypoxanthine analog.

Drugs used in the management of gout can be classified as:

Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain- These drugs are useful in the management of acute attacks of gout. They are:

  • NSAIDs: They mainly exert their antiinflammatory action by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX). This enzyme converts arachidonic acid to prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins
  • Colchicine: It arrests the cell division by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. This results in decreased neutrophil recruitment decreased neutrophil motility and decreased release of chemotactic factors. 
  • Glucocorticoids: These drugs bind to the nuclear receptors and decrease the transcription of genes for COX-2, inducible NOS (NOS2), inflammatory cytokines, collagenase, etc, that are responsible for inflammation.

Drugs that inhibit urate formation- These drugs inhibit urate formation by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Eg. allopurinol and febuxostat. The most common adverse effect of allopurinol is hypersensitivity reactions. Oxypurinol is a metabolite of allopurinol and inhibits xanthine oxidase thus reducing uric acid production. It is an orphan drug and is used in patients intolerant to allopurinol.  

Other options:

Option A: Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive. 

Option B: NSAIDs: They mainly exert their antiinflammatory action by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX). This enzyme converts arachidonic acid to prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins

Option C: Uricosuric drugs: These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid. Important ones are:

  • Probenecid- it inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting organic acid transporter (OATs), principally URAT-1.
  • Benzbromarone- It increases uric acid secretion by reversibly inhibiting urate–anion exchanger in the proximal tubule
  • Lesinurad- It inhibits the URAT-1 and OAT-4 transporters, thereby reducing renal uric acid reabsorption.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent opioid analgesic from the options given below?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, fentanyl is the most potent opioid.

Opioid potency:

Sufentanil > Fentanyl > Morphine > Pentazocin and pethidine.

Note: Overall, Sufentanil is the most potent opioid. It is 1000 times more potent than morphine.

Other high-yield points on opioids:

  • Post-thoracotomy pain managed by: IV fentanyl
  • Drug of choice for controlling severe pain in cancer patients: Morphine
  • Drug of choice for OPD analgesia: Alfentanyl
  • Most potent: Sufentanyl
  • Shortest-acting opioid: Remifentanyl

Other options:

Option A: Fentanyl is around 100 times more potent than morphine.

Options C & D: The potency of pentazocin and pethidine is lower than that of morphine

questions.text:
The antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV is:

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
Foscarnet is the antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV.

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog. It does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity. It inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting HSV DNA polymerase and HIV reverse transcriptase.

Foscarnet is used to treat acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus (genital herpes) and varicella-zoster virus infections and ganciclovir-resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is also used as an alternative agent in CMV retinitis in AIDS, and CMV viremia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Common side effects of foscarnet include nephrotoxicity and hypocalcemia.

Foscarnet is mainly excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, dose reduction is necessary for renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity.

Other options:

Option B: Trifluridine is a pyrimidine antimetabolite antiviral drug. It acts against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, and CMV. It is approved for use in herpes simplex keratitis.

Option C: Acyclovir is active against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, varicella-zoster virus, Ebstein Barr virus, and partially against CMV. It is useful against a variety of herpes simplex infections like genital herpes, mucocutaneous herpes, herpes simplex encephalitis, keratitis, and chickenpox.

Option D: Famcyclovir is active against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. It is used as a second-line agent for genital or orolabial herpes.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options:

Option A: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option C: Meclizine is a long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness. It is less sedative and less anticholinergic.

Option D: Scopolamine (hyoscine) is a muscarinic antagonist. It blocks neural pathways from the vestibular apparatus in the inner ear to the emetic center in the brainstem. A transdermal patch of scopolamine is used as an antiemetic in motion sickness. Constipation, drowsiness, dry mouth, and blurred vision are the common adverse effects.

questions.text: Cardiotoxicity is an adverse effect of which of the following anti-cancer drugs?
questions.solution:
Cardiotoxicity is a unique adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Anthracyclines:

They work by interacting with DNA directly and affecting transcription and replication. They have the potential to create free radicals which cause irreversible cardiotoxicity and cardiomyopathy which is dose-dependent.

Adverse effects:

  • Cardiomyopathy is the most common adverse effect and it can be either acute, in the form of myocardial damage("pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome"), or a chronic form of dose-dependent cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure.
  • Alopecia, anemia, amenorrhea, leukopenia, nausea, vomiting.
  • Mucositis, diarrhea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Less common: acute lymphoid leukemia,acute myelogenous leukemia,atrioventricular block,esophagitis,hyperpigmentation,myelodysplastic syndrome

Anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: The drug of choice for the management of hyperthyroidism in the third trimester of pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the management of hyperthyroidism in the third trimester of pregnancy is methimazole.

Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy:

Pre-pregnancy and first trimester: Propylthiouracil 

2nd, 3rd trimester + post-pregnancy:

  • Methimazole
  • Partial thyroidectomy (in 2nd trimester if methimazole is not effective)

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Propranolol will help with her heart rate (is the patient is symptomatic), but will not help with the overactive thyroid.

If a pregnant woman is on propylthiouracil in her first trimester, she should be switched to methimazole in her 2nd trimester.

Note (in pregnancy):

  • Lowest possible dose should be prescribed
  • Radioiodine therapy contraindicated
Trimester Treatment for thyrotoxicosis
First trimester
  • Propylthiouracil
Second trimester
  • Methimazole
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester
  • Methimazole

Abnormalities associated with methimazole (when used in 1st trimester):

  • Choanal atresia
  • Aplasia cutis
  • Fetal goiter
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Scalp defects

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking regular medications for the past 3 months. Which of the following medication is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction.
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.
  • Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives.

Other options:

Option A: Common side effects of ACE inhibitors like enalapril include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness.

Option B: Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARBs), causes adverse effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, rashes, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

questions.text: A patient started on an antihypertensive presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows edema over the lips and face and its occurrence following intake of an antihypertensive is suggestive of drug-induced angioedema. Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor), is most likely responsible for this condition.

Angioedema with ACE inhibitors:

In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely. 

ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.
  • It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug.
  • Hyperkalemia due to K+ retention can occur.
  • Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.
  • It should be discontinued in pregnant women as it can cause developmental defects.
  • It can also cause maculopapular skin rash in some cases.

Other options:

Option B: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. Common adverse effects include headache, flushing, and dizziness. Peripheral edema (pedal edema) may rarely occur.

Option C: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist. Bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities are common adverse effects. CNS side effects like nightmares and depression are less frequent with atenolol than other beta-blockers.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. The main adverse effects of clonidine are dry mouth and sedation. Bradycardia and sexual dysfunction are other effects.

questions.text: Postural hypotension is a side effect of which of the following classes of drugs?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced orthostatic/postural hypotension is caused by the effect of alpha-blocker (alpha1 - selective receptor blocker).

Alpha1 receptor blockers, such as prazosin, cause a reduction of peripheral resistance as well as venous pooling of blood. This causes a decrease in venous return and cardiac output leading to a fall in blood pressure. Postural reflex causes marked postural hypotension which leads to syncope. This dizziness and fainting are known as the first dose effect and can be minimized by starting with a minimal dose and titrating it thereafter. Other side effects include reflex tachycardia, miosis, nasal congestion, and impotence. 

They are used as an antihypertensive agent and in benign hypertrophy of the prostate to decrease prostatic tone.

The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of α1A receptors over other α1 receptor subtypes. α1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, selective α1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to non-selective α1 antagonists like prazosin.

α1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:

  • Selective antagonists
    • Silodosin (α1A)
    • Tamsulosin (α1A + α1D)
  • Non-selective 
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Doxazosin
    • Alfuzosin

Other options:

Option A: Side effects of Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhibitors include - dry cough, hyperkalemia, angioedema, renal Impairment

Option B: Side effects of Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers (ARB) - hyperkalemia, dizziness

Option C: Side effects of thiazide diuretics include- hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperuricemia, hyperglycemia

questions.text: While conducting animal studies, a scientist is experimenting with a drug called vesamicol that causes skeletal muscle relaxation. What is the mechanism by which the drug causes muscle relaxation?

choices.text: Breakdown of acetylcholine after its release into the synaptic cleft
Blocks the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle
Inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals
Prevents the release of  acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.solution:
Vesamicol causes skeletal muscle relaxation by blocking the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle.

It acts on the cholinergic nerve terminals and blocks the transport, thus preventing the repletion of acetylcholinesterase following transmitter release. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft to acetate and choline.

Option C: Hemicholinum inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals.

Option D: Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.text: Contraceptive failure while on oral contraceptive pills is unlikely to occur with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Contraceptive failure in patients on the oral contraceptive pill is unlikely to occur with valproate. It is an enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the degradation of OCPs and increases their duration of action.

Rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers and can cause increased metabolism of OCPs leading to contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the treatment of the condition?

choices.text: Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning
Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning
Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate poisoning. Pralidoxime is used to counter the nicotinic effects of organophosphates. It reactivates the acetylcholinesterase, which had been deactivated in organophosphate poisoning. 

Atropine is useful in organophosphate poisoning because it is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine. An acetylcholinesterase enzyme has an active and anionic site. The organophosphates bind to the active site of AChEs (acetylcholine esterases) and deactivate it. This results in excessive Ach causing excessive muscarinic activity. It has relatively insignificant action on nicotinic receptors. 

Organophosphates and carbamates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. While carbamates bind reversibly, organophosphates bind irreversibly.  

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Patients who present with organophosphate and carbamate poisoning require early endotracheal intubation to avoid respiratory depression, which is a common complication. Succinylcholine is avoided due to its metabolism by acetylcholinesterase which leads to prolonged neuromuscular blockade.
